rows.name: top_text
rows.value: Teenagers deal with loss in different ways, just like adults do. You can help them understand the situation and their feelings by creating safe spaces where you can both share and process.

rows.name: text_1
rows.value:
- Tell your teen that the person has died - sometimes they do not realise. 
- Telling is a process, not an event. You may need to tell them again and again.  
- Use words they understand.   
- If younger teens don’t understand what death is, help explain that the person they love is not coming back. Try not to call it ‘sleep’ or ‘a trip away’.  
- Older teens may understand what death is, but they may struggle to share or handle their emotions.  
- Teens can respond in very different ways: crying, shouting, not believing or going very quiet. All of these are okay. Tell them that you are there with them. 
- Allow questions and talking. Be honest. It is okay to say when we don’t know.

rows.name: text_2
rows.value:
- Teens might be sad, angry, not understand or not believe it, feel numb, feel unwell or have pains, nightmares or problems at school. Your teen may seem happy, but still be sad. They may get closed off and want to spend more time with friends. They may also show unexpected or dangerous behaviour. These may not make sense to you, but all of this is normal. 
- Teens may feel like it was their fault – that they passed on the virus, or that they behaved badly. Tell them clearly that they did nothing wrong.

rows.name: text_3
rows.value:
- Explain that grief comes with many emotions and reactions. Show your teen that they are loved and cared for, and encourage them to share their emotions by talking, writing or drawing. 
- If there is a support group that your teen can be part of, this can help. 
- If a teen talks about wanting to hurt or kill themselves, ask for help from someone as soon as you can. 
- If you can, keep your normal daily routines, this can be comforting for teens. 
- It can help for teens to be part of rituals around death - to choose a song or something to say. 
- Spending a few minutes every day focused on your teen helps to make them feel more secure and give them a chance to relax or talk about things that are upsetting them.
